2. Interpreting structured categories as presheaves with extensions
A standard sketch $\mathbb{C}$ for categories is like our previous base category
but with additional morphisms for identity and composition (and more).
If we want to reason about pullbacks, we can reify diagram shapes of interest
as new objects in an augmented base.
(a morphism which is a composite of two potentially different composable pairs.)

d) Output for universal property of pullback.
Same, but with mediating morphism $\leadsto$ diagram shape $\mathit{ouppb}$. Exercise.
\textbf{Proposition.} $\llbracket\mathscr{X}\rrbracket$ has (unique for the first $n$) extensions along the following morphisms.
-\ The current diagram is modelled as a finite presheaf on $\mathbb{C}[\mathit{pb}]$, say $S$.
-\  Its semantics is modelled as a morphism $S → \llbracket\mathscr{X}\rrbracket$ to the representation of the considered category $\mathscr{X}$.
-\ Reasoning rules are merely some fixed morphisms along which we know $\llbracket\mathscr{X}\rrbracket$ admits extensions, e.g., $\mathit{iuppb} → \mathit{ouppb}$
